question: ... No, bell hasn't rung yet. Okay, let's get inside. C'mon. ... Morning, morning. Rise and shine.
answer: ... Damn skippy.

question: Thank you for sharing, Auggie.
answer: ... Auggie doggie.

question: 'Scuse me, you two... this isn't the Playboy Channel. 'Morning, Juanita. Let's get started. August and Tywan, you pass out the books. Thank you, gentlemen.
answer: Whas up wit' your car, G? Yer Pinto blow up?

question: No, I don't own a Pinto, Tywan. Okay, can I have everyone's attention? The purpose of the bicycle is to demonstrate the principle of centripetal force. That's the opposite of the force we studied yesterday, which was... Centrifugal force... Centripetal force is where the acceleration of a body moving in circular motion is directed toward its center by an opposing force, thus creating momentum that constrains the body to its circular path. Like a gyroscope. It's better if I show you. Here, Tywan, you be my helper. Tywan? Come on.
answer: Whad-up, G? Hey, shut up! Y'all too damn loud, man!

question: I need you to demonstrate centripetal force. Here, have a seat. Okay, hold the bike steady with your knees. That's it. Seat positioned against your chest.
answer: Shut up, foo.

question: Okay, now crank the pedals and get that back wheel spinning about
answer: Whas up wit' dat?

question: You'll see. Be patient. ... Put some muscle into it. ... Keep pedaling. Harder.
answer: Whas up? I tol' you you was crazy, man.

question: Now tilt the wheel to your right.
answer: Aw, damn. I'm spinnin'. Lookit me, Auggie!

question: Walter, I need to speak with you.
answer: I'm pretty busy right now, Garfield. What is it?

question: Could you open it, please?
answer: Don't suppose this kid cares about our budget crisis? Have the textbook room charge him for the book.

question: One-Eight-Seven is a penal code number for murder, Walter. Means the same thing as T-O-S. 'Terminate On the Spot.'
answer: For chrissake, I know what it stands for. Look, kid probably heard it in a rap song. Doesn't mean anything.

question: ... The book belongs to Dennis Broadway. He's a known gangster, Walter -- a 'Five Percenter.'
answer: Garfield, if I had a dollar for every time a student threatened faculty... Don't you think you're overreacting a little?

question: Did you tell Dennis Broadway he was getting a fail from me?
answer: I have legal access to those files.

question: He's a transfer from Nixon High School, isn't he?
answer: Look, I'm not obligated to track you down every time a transfer student comes through here. You want confidential information like that, come look it up in his cum .

question: Do you have him on a contract?
answer: If he gets through the semester without a fail then he gets to go back to Nixon, so what?

question: ... and be with his homeboys.
answer: So he blew his opportunity. Now he has to learn to live with the consequences.

question: I don't think this kid's ready to deal with the consequences. I think he wants me dead.
answer: Relax, has nothin' to do with you.

question: I should have been told, Walter.
answer: Hey, I'm on your side, Garfield, but my hands are tied. Kid has a right to his privacy... Know what your problem is? You're an idealist.

question: What's wrong with that?
answer: You only see what you wanna see, that's what's wrong. On one hand you think someone's trying to kill you. On the other hand you actually believe kids are paying attention in your classes.

question: Never mind. It's not a problem.
answer: Tell you what, as soon as I get a chance I'll summons the kid. Promise.

question: Morning... ... Yes, uh huh. ... If you're listening, God, please help me today. All I ask is a chance to do my job... t'do the job you put me here to do in the first place. Please help me accept those things I cannot change... and give me strength to change those things I can. ... This is me, Trevor, God. Amen.
answer: ... Baseball cap, give it up. Hold it, please.

question: I'm a substitute.
answer: Okay, you want the Main Office, straight ahead. Check in with Mrs. Ford.

question: ... Before taking roll, I'd like to prove a point.
answer: 'Farfie?' Whad up, Farfie?

question: ... It's not important what... or who... 'Farfie' is. Yuh wanna play, yuh gotta stay. Have a seat, please. The point I'd like to make is this... Anyone here can be a scientist. ... A scientist is like a detective. He investigates data. He scratches the surface of things he doesn't understand to see what's underneath. ... Things like this. Okay, who wants to read?
answer: I'll do it.

question: Come on, we don't need disrespect. Let 'im do it. What's your name?
answer: Barsek.

question: Okay, Barsek. Read.
answer: ... Glis was very frapper. She had denarpen Farfie's Mardsen. She couldn't galp a giberter for Farfie. Instead she wharked to plimp a mardsen binky for him.

question: You know how the books got outside?
answer: No speaky Engless. You speak Spanish, Mister... Whas yer name?

question: Garfield.
answer: ... You speak Spanish, Mister G? Eh, G... know what dat means when a homeboy calls you 'G'? Dat means gangster, homes. You a gangster, maestro?

question: No, I'm not a gangster. Would you please do me a favor and pick up the books?
answer: Andate a la mierda. I ain't pickin' dat shit up. You go pick it up.

question: What's your name?
answer: Cesar Chavez. Don't you recognize me? See dis? I'm already on house arrest, homes. Ain't nothin' more you can do to me.

question: Shut yer mouth, hood rat! School girl bitch!
answer: Okay, Benny. That's enough.

question: Hey, you ain't no real teacher. Fool, you're nothin' but a sub. T'ink yer so cool... You mus' be 'Mr. culo.'
answer: Why do you wear a rosary?

question: Ain't none a' yer damn business. To put God on me, okay? Why don't you jus' go sit down and read yer newspaper. Wanna-be, mother fucker.
answer: Are you done?

question: Jus' gimme a referral. Shit.
answer: For future reference, anyone who disrupts a class, or in any way infringes on the rights of others to get an education, is subject to disciplinary action. When I'm here, ladies and gentlemen, I expect to be treated decently... ... hopefully in an atmosphere of mutual respect. This classroom is our sanctuary, yours and mine. Respect it. For your information, I am a real teacher.

question: Whatever you say, Opie.
answer: Okay, who would like to help me pick up the books?

question: Trevor Garfield.
answer: Nice scar yuh got there. Ever sub here before?

question: First time.
answer: What about permanent?

question: I taught seven years in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. Roosevelt Whitney High School.
answer: Roosevelt Whitney? Didn't some teacher get stabbed to death there last year?

question: Actually, he survived.
answer: No, it was on 'Sixty Minutes.' Some gangbanger stabbed this guy with a ten-penny nail like a dozen times in a hallway and... Jesus Christ, you're him. It was you. Holy shit, Garfield. When was that? December before last? No, it was fall.

question: October 27.
answer: Whadda schmuck. I'm sittin' here givin' advice to a man with a purple heart.

question: Lemme tell yuh somethin'. In my book you're a fuckin' hero. Damn straight.
answer: ... Getting stabbed doesn't make me a hero.

question: So what'd they give the kid?
answer: They put 'im upstate in a facility until his twenty-first birthday.

question: That all? They shoulda caned the bastard. Like they did that kid in Singapore. Remember? President of Singapore had a few choice words. Use to have it memorized... He said something like, 'When a state of increasing disorder and defiance cannot be checked by the rules... then new and sometimes drastic rules have to be forged to maintain order.' 'The alternative is to surrender order to chaos and anarchy.'
answer: So why do you still teach?

question: Same reason as you, Garfield -- for the paycheck.
answer: Okay, someone tell me the difference between the central nervous system and the lymphatic system?

question: Okay, someone tell me the difference between the central nervous system and the lymphatic system?
answer: Mr. G, you gotta nice butt.

question: You seem to be an expert on anatomy, Miss -- -- Nartinez. Central nervous system and lymphatic system. What's the difference?
answer: ... Uh... It's like the central nervous system, that's your brain and spinal cord, and the lymphatic system, that's the stuff in your blood that fights diseases.

question: Very good. Cesar. You writing on your desk?
answer: You see anything in my hands? I don't think so.

question: K-O-S, what's that? That a tagging crew? Cartoon... Is that you, Cesar? 'K-O-S' has something to do with your friend Benny?
answer: ... Dawg. You're a sucker. K-O-S stands for 'Kappin' Off Suckers.' Don't disrespect my homeboy, Benny. He don't like it. He don't like you.

question: God forbid anyone should think that. shifts his gaze from them to the venetian blinds framing the window... to the clock over his desk.
answer: May I come in?

question: Yeah... ... Ellen. I'm making time a reward instead of a distraction.
answer: Clever... Listen, I wanted to apologize for jumping up like I did at lunch. I was just feeling a little weird...

question: It's alright.
answer: For what it's worth, Dave Childress thinks you walk on water.

question: Is that a good thing?
answer: I think it takes a lot of courage to go back into a classroom after something like that.

question: Not if the only thing you ever wanted to do was teach.
answer: Now you see, there's our predicament. I assume you've met Benny Chacon?

question: I have.
answer: Last week Benny and his tagging crew had Ms. Eskander pinned in the corner over there. ... She's seven months pregnant and he's tormenting her with a broom handle... Can I help you with those?

question: No thanks.
answer: So anyway, Gloria kicks Benny... and if the district construes it as assault and battery on a student, she's gone.

question: They'd do that?
answer: In a heart beat. She's non- tenured, they don't want to get sued... Don't be surprised if she files for stress leave by the end of the week. Too bad, too. She's a good teacher. Can I ask you a personal question? Why'd that kid attack you?

question: Because I flunked him.
answer: Is there any way you can see something like that coming?

question: When they say they wanna kill you, you'd best take it serious. This kid was an O.T. -- Opportunity Transfer -- but nobody told me until it was too late.
answer: Did you know Benny's an O.T.?... In less than a year he's been convicted of felony assault and suspended twice. I even testified against him as a character witness. Now I get to see him every day in homeroom. I'm stuck with him. Condition of his probation is that he stay in school.

question: You talk to the principal?
answer: Many times... Three weeks ago, Garcia calls Benny's mother in for a conference, but she refuses to show up. She's afraid they'll deport her because she's illegal. So she contacts the A.C.L.U. and some attorney tells her she doesn't have to come in. Garcia got cold feet and dropped the whole thing. This kid's threatening me and all he's worried about is a lawsuit.

question: What'd Benny say to you?
answer: That he wanted to hurt me. Real bad.

question: Does he know where you live?
answer: I think so. Someone's been phoning me at night and hanging up... Two weeks ago, my car was broken into... And last Friday, I think he was inside my house... But I can't prove it. ... I don't know what to do.

question: You can quit.
answer: You didn't.

question: ... Trevor.
answer: Eskander filed for stress leave. They want me to finish out the semester.

question: That's great...
answer: It's only 'til the end of the year.

question: Listen, I never thanked you for letting me cry on your shoulder.
answer: That's okay.

question: Hey, have you seen Benny lately? Ford told me he hasn't phoned his P.O. in four days. You know what they say. Be careful what you pray for. Don't get me wrong, Benny's made my life a living hell. I even moved back in with my mother because of him. I love my mother, but if I eat one more dinner off a TV tray or watch one more rerun of 'Wheel of Fortune,' I think I'll lose my fucking mind. Time's up. Everyone stop working. ... So you have a wife hiding in a closet somewhere?
answer: No. No wife.

question: Don't you ever get lonely?
answer: Sometimes. There's this passage in God's Lonely Man by Thomas Wolfe where he says, '... The whole conviction of my life rests upon the belief that loneliness is the central and inevitable fact of human existence.' I believe that.

question: God that's depressing.
answer: ... My New York mentality. It's not always easy looking on the bright side.

question: Especially after spending a year in and out of a hospital, I would guess.
answer: Actually, that wasn't the toughest part -- it's the robbery that's been hardest to recover from.

question: What'd they steal?
answer: My passion. My old, unguarded self. I resent that. I want them back.

question: They're still there. Everybody around me seems to have given up. They're all so beaten down. But you're different. You refuse to be beaten.
answer: So do you.

question: Remember the last time a student surprised you?
answer: You mean where a light goes on?

question: Yeah. Where the kid surpasses all your expectations.
answer: ... Been awhile. So few you can actually get through to... You?

question: ... That would have to be Daniel Terrazas. This was last year sometime. Kid was failing miserably ... But he was the best Salsa dancer in the whole school.
answer: Uh-oh.

question: So I made 'im a deal. Tutoring in exchange for Salsa lessons.
answer: Saw it... Jerry Springer.

question: No, no. He was a perfect gentleman.
answer: Male teachers can't do things like that. They get arrested.

question: Yep, double standard... By the way, did you know Cesar Sanchez was Special Ed? Yep, he never should've been mainstreamed. His I.E.P. says he's L.H. but he acts more like S.E.D.
answer: Severely Emotionally Disturbed... that's great.

question: Come on, Garfield -- on your feet. Lemme teach you how to Salsa.
answer: No, no, I'm no good at that.

question: Let's go. Don't play shy with me, homeboy. That's it... Okay, follow me. It starts on the one. Step forward with your left foot... One. Change weight on, two. And three, feet back together... Now do the same in reverse, starting with your right foot. One, two, three... One, two three... Oh, my God... your shirt. Oh, no, I'm so sorry.
answer: It's alright.

question: Can I help?
answer: Grab the baking soda outta the fridge.

question: Don't start barking, Jack.
answer: Hey there, boy. You're a good dog. Yes, you are.

question: Sorry for reacting the way I did back there.
answer: Don't apologize. That's how most people react.

question: Didn't scare me. It just surprised me. ... Thanks for dinner. I had a good time.
answer: You're welcome.

question: Here... you need a little life in that place of yours.
answer: ... Good night.

question: ... Night.
answer: Since some of you seem to have an interest in anesthetics, I've prepared a little demonstration. Rita, bring your friend in the cage over here, please.

question: You read Animal Farm, Cesar?
answer: No, but I fucked a sheep.

question: Cesar, come up here. I want you to have a front row seat for this. And remove the 'lokes.' Why your eyes so red?
answer: Mus' be pink-eye, sir. Nice watch, homes. Can I have it?

question: Rita, would you bring me a sugar cube from the shelf over there? Cesar, read Young's rule for us. Page 564. At the top.
answer: I ain't gonna read 'dat shit.

question: Rita, give Cesar your book. Let 'im read.
answer: Forget it.

question: You just caught a murder case, homes.
answer: Okay, anyone who didn't finish answering the questions on 246, finish them for homework. Hold it, Cesar. Where's my watch?

question: Hey, I gotta go. I ain't got no watch.
answer: Empty your pockets, both of you.

question: Want me to break it down to you? I gotta catch a bus.
answer: Sorry. I'm trying to catch Hyland before he leaves. I've been meaning to come by your room.

question: Sorry. I'm trying to catch Hyland before he leaves. I've been meaning to come by your room.
answer: ... It's almost been a week. My guess is you're avoiding me. You okay?

question: Has nothing to do with you, Ellen. It's... hard for me... Pretty much been like that since... you know, my accident. Has nothing to do with you.
answer: Is it because I'm white?

question: No.
answer: We can still be friends. Just don't pull away. Now, can I ask you a favor? After you're done with Hyland, can you give me a ride to my car? It's at the mechanics, about five or six blocks up Lankershim. If you can't, it's okay, I can walk.

question: ... I think I can manage that.
answer: Que paso, Victor?

question: You don't mind if I tape record our conversation. Matter of record. You understand. Of course, you know Mr. Hyland.
answer: Am I being questioned?

question: Mr. Sanchez and Mr. Littleton tell me you've accused them of stealing your watch. If that's the case, I need to address the accusation.
answer: ... For the record, I primarily suspect Mr. Sanchez. Although I wouldn't be surprised if Stevie was an accomplice. Beginning of sixth period, Cesar admired the watch. I believe his exact words were, 'Can I have it?' Either way, I'd like my watch back.

question: Anything else?
answer: When I asked him to empty his pockets, Cesar refused.

question: Is that true, Mr. Sanchez?
answer: No way. He never asked me nothin' like that! I don't go 'round taxing no teachers...

question: Okay. Calm down.
answer: ... I ain't got no watch, man.

question: Mr. Littleton, may we see your pockets too?
answer: I'd like a locker search, please.

question: You're excused, gentlemen. Take your things. Thank you. ... Let me try and explain something. I try and think of our students here at John Quincy Adams like they're my clients. I can't accuse anybody just on your hunches. I need more than that. I need facts. I won't have another law suit like we did with that Blackwell case. Boy's mother spent $400 that she couldn't afford on new clothes for her son. Unfortunately we considered the clothing gang attire and sent the boy home. That cost the district a quarter of a million dollars. So I want you to be straight with me, Mr. Garfield. Did you physically see Cesar take your watch?
answer: No, I didn't...

question: Do you have any witnesses who saw him take it?

Unless there's reasonable cause to show that Cesar, or Mr. Littleton took your watch then I can't authorize a locker search. I'm sorry. Any concerns regarding my decision, you can look up in the handbook. It's section 628.1 of the Education Code.
answer: That was my grandfather's watch. Can't you see what they're doing? Weren't you ever a teacher?

question: Yeah, fine, go ahead. I'll wait.
answer: ... I have to fly up there for a computer conference.

question: When's that?
answer: Day after tomorrow.

question: Never been to San Francisco.
answer: Oh, you should go sometime, Trevor. I think you'd like it. Really. It's only an hour by air. Maybe five or six by car. Completely different attitude from L.A. Much more like a real city... like Chicago or New York... ... Only problem is I hate to leave Jack with my mother for any extended period of time. I'm afraid she'll forget to feed him and he'll starve to death.

question: If you want, I'll take care of Jack.
answer: I can't ask you to do that.

question: Sure you can. ... Aren't you supposed to be at P.E. fifth period?
answer: ... Sunland Boyz gettin' crazy, ol lady's... fucked up. Fuck dis being down shit. I wanna do somethin' wit' my life.

question: ... You know this guy?
answer: 'Gotta make J-C next year. 'Got to! I ain't never gonna get up outta here.

question: Rita, slow down.
answer: 'Dat bitch Quinn, I'm 'onna sue her ass. 'Swear tuh God...

question: Okay, okay. Calm down a second. Who's Quinn? What's she teach?
answer: English Comp. She's failin' me. 'Bitch say I don't talk right. She hates me. She's racist against me.

question: Just cause you're a Latina doesn't mean everyone's racist against you.
answer: Hey, I'm a La Raza, prof-eh.

question: Okay... just stop blaming everyone else. You're too smart for that. And every mistake in that essay is fixable, okay? So relax, it's not the end of the world. Tissues are in the first drawer. How come you always wear so much makeup?
answer: ... To make me pretty.

question: You don't need it. That your name?
answer: It's a gang thing. But I'm kickin' dat shit... Jus' cuz I look down for my neighborhood don't mean I'm stupit.

question: I know you're not. The ideas in your essay aren't the problem, Rita. It's your punctuation and grammar. They need work. Am I lying? If you want help I'm here for you. Okay?
answer: ... I dunno.

question: Have to be in the library after school.
answer: ... Somebody could see us.

question: All right then, I'll come to your house.
answer: No... No way.

question: Where then? You name the place.
answer: Dog, you invadin' my privacy. Bitch.

question: Cesar, would you come up here please? Since you were so concerned, I though you might like to know... I found my watch.
answer: ... You broke into my locker. Dat's a serious felony, prof-eh. You caught a case for sure now.

question: Whadda yuh propose to do, Cesar? Tell Garcia? Whadda yuh gonna tell 'im? That I broke into your locker to steal back the watch you denied taking? I don't think so. I'd say we're even now, wouldn't you, Cesar?
answer: No, I'd say we're just getting started, ese.

question: Want something to drink? We have Coke, Fanta or Sprite...
answer: ... Coke's awright.

question: 'Want you to know, you're not the only one risking a reputation here. Normally I don't tutor students at my house. Rita, maybe you can clear something up. Can you explain to me what machismo is all about? Cuz this whole respect/code of honor thing baffles me. Ask yourself this question. Is pride really that important? Put your clothes on, Rita. No harm done... Don't cry now. Why don't you go ahead and copy the first rule there for the verb 'to be.' Can you do that for me?
answer: I jus' wan'ed to thank you.

question: You don't have to thank me, I'm your teacher. ... From now on I think the best thing for us to do is meet in the library. (prayerfully, to himself ... I'll try.
answer: I ain't getting it. You get it.

question: Hello, Cesar.
answer: Puto! You lied to Benny. You said you don't speak no Spanish!

question: No I didn't.
answer: 'At's bullshit!

question: Enjoy hitting your mother, Cesar? You must be proud of yourself.
answer: ... He's lyin', man. Fuckin' liar! Homeboy don't never disrespec' his mother. Never. You hear me, joto?!

question: Whatever you say, Cesar.
answer: I'll find out where you stay. Trucha, homes! Valla ala chingada!

question: He didn't do anything. He's a good kid. Been smokin' the chronic, Cesar?
answer: I'm hooked on phonics... not 'hooked on chronic.'

question: You wouldn't happen t'know who vandalized bungalow eighty-six last night?
answer: You guys know anything about that? Sorry, maestro... nada.

question: Garcia may not think there's enough here to prove anything. But you and I both know who's responsible. Don't we?
answer: Whadda you, a narc? Seriously, I don't know what the fuck you're talkin' about.

question: The ring, Cesar... lemme have it.
answer: Watch it, eh... that's my trigger finger.

question: It's inappropriate attire...
answer: ... Bang.

question: ... Are you finished?
answer: What? Finished with what? Don't get crazy on me, dude.

question: ... These conferences mainly focus on software now.
answer: Software sells.

question: So, how's Jack?
answer: ... Jack's good.

question: And what about Trevor? Was Trevor a good boy, too?
answer: What's that supposed to mean?

question: Nothing...
answer: Is that supposed to mean something?

question: Trevor...
answer: Can't you see I'm talking to the lady?! ... I'm sorry. Forgive me.

question: ... Come out, come out, wherever you are. Where is he?
answer: Jack?

question: Here, boy... here, Jack. Come to Mommy, sweetheart. ... Oh, my God. Jack?! Jack! ... Jack.
answer: It's aspirin...

question: ... I can't talk to you right now, Trevor. Please. I'm so upset I can't even drive. I just need some time alone.
answer: I know about what's not fair. I left part of my lung in a damn hospital because some gangbanger didn't like the grade I gave him. Sometimes you do all the right things. You work hard in school... get a good job... pay your taxes. Things still go bad. I'm so sorry, Ellen.

question: Good. ... And don't forget the phalanges. May I come in?
answer: Hi.

question: Where'd you go the other night?
answer: I was going to ask you the same thing.

question: ... I went for a run. Wanna get some Chinese later? There's a new place in the Valley Center. 'Spose to be pretty good.
answer: ... Can't tonight. Maybe another time.

question: ... I should probably correct papers anyway. Some of these bungalow kids actually care about a grade. Even Cesar's doing better. Today, for the first time since I took over for Eskander, he actually did his work. Today Cesar Sanchez was a success. Maybe for the first time in his life. You alright?
answer: ... Much better, thank you.

question: ... I really am sorry about Jack.
answer: ... Finished.

question: ... Let's hava look.. ... Good. ... I was just thinking, since your essay's about gangs and getting away from their influence, you probably could've left some of those double negatives you like so well.
answer: So now you wan' me to use bad grammar.

question: Only if it suits your topic.
answer: I know. We're all products of our environment 'n' shit.

question: No, I think that's just an excuse. I say if we're strong, we can rise above adversity. But it's like rap or hip-hop... Correct all the grammar and it loses its impact.
answer: So you like hip-hop, Mr. G?

question: ... I hate it.
answer: What kinda black man are you? Why you here anyways? Don't you got nothin' better t'do?

question: ... Everything I wanna do is right here. It's a good essay, Rita. You put a lot of effort into it, it shows.
answer: Comes from the heart, maestro. I'm a writer... not a fighter.

question: ... Ms. Quinn was telling me she picks two seniors each year to read their essays at graduation.
answer: She ain't gonna pick my paper. Anyway, I don't wanna get up in fronna all those people and make a fool outta myself.

question: Why not? It'd be a Pyrrhic victory.
answer: What's dat?

question: You're right, Stevie. I can't afford to live in a big house south of the boulevard. Like you do. Iris, did Steven Littleton come in here? Sue me. ... Espanol, muy poquito, senora. Mrs. Chacon... you have to slow down. What's she saying? ... Four, almost five weeks. So he just sits here? She said he has some pockmarks on his chest; from a bad case of chicken pox. And there's a bar- code tattoo on his neck. Did you find any rosary beads with the body?
answer: ... Who's there?

question: You should keep your door locked.
answer: What's the matter?

question: I just want you to tell me one thing...
answer: What? What is it?

question: ... If you had any idea what I've been thinking lately... you'd think I was crazy. ... Remember that John Doe they found in the L.A. River. Turned out it was Benny.
answer: Who told you that?

question: ... Benny's mother identified the body.
answer: Benny was no saint, Ellen. This is a kid who terrorized hald the school. He even broke into your house. Maybe we should think about that 'fore we shed any tears. ... Maybe he's better off.

question: That's a horrible thing to say.
answer: Do you believe for every troubled kid like Benny there's one or two others just waiting to take his place? Like Cesar... or his friend Stevie.

question: You don't know anything about Cesar's finger, do you, Trevor?
answer: Sometimes a person just runs out of bad choices. Then he's gotta pay a price. What happened to Cesar was inevitable.

question: You're scaring me.
answer: We make choices in life and we live by 'em. You and I chose to be teachers, to stand on principle. Benny and Cesar, they're takers. They want what they want, and they want it now.

question: Trevor...
answer: I'm sorry but everyone can't always get what they want. Sometimes you gotta take responsibility for your actions. Have you ever been ready to die for a fundamental principle? They haven't. You think those punks would die protecting your Civil Rights?

question: Trevor, don't.
answer: Did you know Cesar hits his mother? Steals money from her purse? Did you know that? Did you know he was here that night? In the alley?

question: What are you talking about?
answer: Cesar. Jack was provoked. It wasn't an accident, Ellen. Cesar killed him.

question: Where'd you get the rosary beads?
answer: I like you, Ellen. I like you so much. Do you believe that?

question: Yes. ... I don't know you.
answer: ... You do know me. I'm a teacher, just like you.

question: School girl bitch!
answer: You gotta problem?!

question: Yer fuckin' maestro, 'at's my problem!
answer: I don't know what yer talkin' 'bout!

question: Garfield killed Benny!
answer: Yer crazy.

question: Don't turn yer back on me when I'm talkin' t'you, bitch. You think yer better than everybody else. Well you ain't! You ain't nuthin' but a whore!
answer: Fuck you, asshole!

question: What? You forget about the time in the bungalows? We all had our turn wit you, man!
answer: Shut up!

question: What the fuck you been fuckin' a nigger for? Huh? You think he's gonna protec' you? Stop me from doin' whatever I want wit' you? Stop any of us from doin' what we want wit' you?!
answer: Fuck you, Cesar.

question: The death... The death of Benito Chacon is not gang-related. That's something you heard on the news. It's wrong. It's misinformation. Thank you, Mrs. Ford. ... The police at this point aren't even sure if it's a case of murder. The reason we're having this meeting tonight is to quash all the rumors floating around out there. Okay. Here's what we do know. Benny Chacon ultimately died from a drug overdose, technically it was morphine. Which is what heroin breaks down into...
answer: ... Dat's bullshit! Benny was no junkie! I know who did it! It's not the gangbangers y'gotta worry about. It's the teachers!

question: That's exactly the type of rumor we don't need, Mr. Littleton.
answer: ... It was Garfield.

question: Say one more word and you're suspended.
answer: You're a fuckin' murderer, Garfield!

question: Victor?
answer: ... Maybe I can't prove it but I know he did it. He fucked up Cesar and he killed Benny. Ast 'im! Touch me and I'll sue yer ass! Yer dead, G! Yer a dead man!

question: Garfield, wait up... ... Don't let that Littleton punk get to you. Lil' bastard's a tweaker. He's a speed freak. You didn't know that?
answer: What is it, Dave? How can I help you?

question: How 'bout a ride? ... The wife wouldn't let me drive my own car. Ain't that a bitch?
answer: ... You smell like beer.

question: I only had two. That's all. Swear ta Christ. I live right up here off Chandler. I'll buy you a drink. ... I had the same situation 'round the time of that 'Night Stalker' thing. Remember that? Whole city was scared shitless. My wife was convinced the frickin' mailman was the 'Stalker' for about a week there. Some mental giant in my 4th period starts this rumor, see. Childress is the 'Night Stalker.' Right? ... Idiots. Even after they caught that Ramirez jerk, I'd still hear those fucks '... They got the wrong guy. Childress is the Stalker, ese.'
answer: I better get goin'. Thanks for the soda.

question: Wait, wait. Hold your horses. Just hold on... ... Can't leave without meetin' the kids. Ta-dah... Huh? ... This one's from Czechoslovakia. It's a C-Z .22 automatic. Ten round clip. Glow- in-the-dark sights. Ain't that a beauty? ... Then we gotta custom Smitty, 9 'milli.' With extended grip. These Smith & Wessons kick like a mutha. Now this one's special. A Glock 21. Lightest gun in the world. The barrel and firing pin are metal. See. Everything else on it's plastic. Here, feel that. ... 'Course you can never be too prepared. My pukey lil' Davis
answer: You wear that thing at school?

question: ... Don't worry. They never use metal detectors on teachers. I also keep a .357 inside my desk. ... But you already know that. Didn't think I was payin' attention, did'ja? Shoulda seen the look on your face. Now, Jose, if I've told you once I've told you a hundred times, stay in your cotton pickin' seat. Boom! Haven't you ever just wanted to blow one of these little bastards away? ... Speaking of blowing, you ever wanna fuck a high school girl, Garfield? 'Caught yer girl, Rita, bustin' a train out in the 'utility' shed couple months back. Swear to God. She had at least five or six cholos lined up back there. Face it, brother, she's a slut. C'mon, I know you had 'er. I even did her.
answer: You're drunk.

question: I know you been laughin' at me behind my back. I'm talkin' about screwin' high school broads and you're givin' off this self-righteous attitude like your shit don't stink. ... Tell me the truth now, Garfield. Did yuh do it? C'mon, I won't tell. Did yuh whack Benny? Whadda 'bout Cesar? That was generous, only taking his finger. I woulda cut off his balls.
answer: ... Go to hell, Dave.

question: You really did it. You son of a bitch.
answer: You probably think you and me are alike. peering toward the library doors. Nothing. Now above the doors...

question: You probably think you and me are alike. peering toward the library doors. Nothing. Now above the doors...
answer: Be nice to your brother, Antonio. Don't make me go get Mommie. Go play wit' your brothers. Whatcha doin' here, maestro?

question: I want you to come back to school, Rita. You can't afford to miss finals. They won't let you graduate.
answer: No way. Forget it. I can't. What's wrong wit' you.

question: Cesar and Stevie won't bother you. That's a promise.
answer: Why'd they have to kill Snowball?

question: ... They didn't.
answer: What's it fuckin' matter?! 'At school shit's for other kids, not me!

question: That's not true. You're so smart, Rita. Don't you know that? You have an opportunity here to change your life. Please don't throw away everything we've worked for. I know what happened with Childress.
answer: What?

question: He won't ever touch you again.
answer: He ain't done nuthin' tuh me. That boy's fulla shit. What's he been sayin'?

question: Doesn't matter.
answer: He ain't never touched me no ways. What's he sayin'? He say he fucked me?! He say dat?! He's a damn liar! Get the fuck outta here! I don't need yer damn pity and I don't need you!

question: But I need you, Rita.
answer: You made a mistake. Dat's all.

question: Rivetted. Now he slides the cardboard box, along with his briefcase onto the front seat.
answer: ... I'd like to apologize for the other night.

question: Shouldn't listen to me. I was half asleep.
answer: We really need to talk.

question: ... Not tonight. Have to finish some work...
answer: Tomorrow then? It's important to me.

question: ... Okay.
answer: ... How 'bout seven o'clock?

question: C'mon, homie.
answer: He took my turn.

question: ... What?
answer: It was my turn. He took it... He dissed me.

question: So fuckin' what, man! He's dead! Let's go!
answer: I gotta do this.

question: Fuck dis shit! Leave it!
answer: I got one chance in six. I'm 'onna beat 'dis bitch... For honor, vato.
